messages: 4354242da3859f2377fd8fc1e1854d63 (21:57): somebody has one howto of emulation of linux
4354242da3859f2377fd8fc1e1854d63 (21:58): or a site wich has this documentation??
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:29): i never feel like adding a ulimit command to my .login is a good idea
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:29): how to i set a system-wide default ulimit?
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:47): yeah if you want a default one I can provide it
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:48): once I get it cleaned up I will get elad to commit it as an example
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:49): I use this for keeping default users from taking down system
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:49): i dont know why the default datasize on netbsd is 128m
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:50): i guess it depends on the machine's role
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:50): yeah my case it was for just giving a free shell account away to testdrive netbsd
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:50): for a personal (about 1 user) desktop role, 128m is too small
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:51): all i have to do is create /etc/login.conf and it will be sued?
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:51): make sure you have no extra spaces at end of lines
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:51): I found it did not parse it otherwise
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:51): and dont forget to update users to include them in a 'class' in /etc/passwd
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:52): Ober: i'm not going to require classes, it is just going to be "default" in my login.conf
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:53): just in case root needs more
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:53): becki didnt you get kicked/banned from ##openbsd?
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (22:54): daveBSD: I tried to upgrade the kernel accordingly to the documentation, left with a system not booting any more
ddfcecab7180be047720000fcedc3667 (22:54): Ober: this nick is not registered, so i have to wait until becki gets offline
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:54): Teppich: did you backup your kernel?
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (22:55): guess i have to reboot for it to take effect
ce8a1609cf8d1a408da3cac46365f53e (22:56): not sure if I had to reboot
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (22:57): ober: of course, just as the documentation tells me to. that's how I  got the system back up again
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (22:58): (fucking around with serial console, boot via rarpd/tftp/nfs...)
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (23:01): I guess it's because the new-kernel is not within the first 1023 cylinder
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (23:01): renaming the old kernel did not move it anywhere,  so that kept on booting fine
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (23:01): this may be a bug with openfirmware (sparc64)
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:03): your root partition isnt in the 1023 cy ?
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:06): then /usr takes up the rest of the drive
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (23:09): I'm using that system to work on (maildir in /home/user/, storing docs etc)
5a88748c4bb3824bcfff53e433213900 (23:09): I do not want to fizzle around with too small partitions or symlinking in the system...
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:16): Teppich: my home is a link to /usr/home
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:34): I have winxp on master hd
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:34): can I install netbsd on hdb, and have its bootloader on hda?
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:35): i tried this with linux, and the bootloader wouldnt load the distro on hdb
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:37): i really dont think that will work
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:38): only 1 HD is selected as the boot device by the BIOS
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:38): and, that is the one that has to have the OS on it
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:38): the OS has to be booted before other disks become visible
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:38): and windows doesnt have a bootloader that would show bsd, right?
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:40): You can make the windows bootloader boot but would you really want to? :)
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:40): but will the windows bootloader boot into BSD?
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:41): trying to find a way around this
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:41): I've done FreeBSD with it and I think the process might work with netbsd
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:41): Booted FreeBSD from the windows bootloader
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:42): You just save the bootsector to a file and add it to the boot.ini
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:42): i really didnt think it was possible
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:43): There's a lot of things possible, doesn't mean you really want to do them. ;-)
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:43): well, if its the only way I can manage it, then sure I do
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:43): better than physically jacking my harddrives around
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:44): pha1sity: how about change the BIOS boot disk :)
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:44): i actually did that for a while

5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:44): I had a friend that did the GRUB thing with multiple hard drives recently. I think it involved some  chainloading, swapping and hiding of drives to get it all to work properly
120c1a571b24dda6aeb4ce84a56ea7db (23:44): to avoid screwing with windows' boot
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:44): GRUB is probably the best option for this
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:44): but will that work with them jumpered to master and slave?
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:45): because I finaly get to try bsd
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:47): i tried freeBSD 5.5 ages ago and had no net
5fb8079c42ea41ee40c9adade2a1f02e (23:47): It was available as a port but you have to have net access to install it. heh
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:48): the docs say nfe works on my chipset so
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:48): so then I cant really get it eh?
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:49): i take it its in alpha?
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:50): i just see that the topics says 3.01
8d102cab8535e4a2d9e4ef284cd63b16 (23:55): http://cvsweb.netbsd.org/bsdweb.cgi/src/sys/dev/pci/if_nfe.c shows it is in netbsd-3 but not netbsd-3-0-1-RELEASE
52c5f30839230c3df2d3bb2c55cbf0b1 (23:57): i have gentoo/linux , if i installe kernel netbsd, i can use the sofware of my gentoo/linux ?
7adb29848bd21c8d64c785b8eb5b3ef5 (23:57): jakllsch, how the hell do you read that thing?
8d102cab8535e4a2d9e4ef284cd63b16 (23:58): Bardamu: you can run Linux apps under NetBSD, but the kernel is not a drop-in replacement for the Linux kernel
8d102cab8535e4a2d9e4ef284cd63b16 (00:00): pha1sity: the tags on the various revisions
